info.game_comments:
2003 College Championship quarterfinal game 3.
From Yale University.

(1, 1).clue: On May 30, 1998 a library devoted to this Confederate President opened at Beauvoir, his Mississippi home

(2, 1).clue: You can download "Wheel of Fortune" onto the Nokia 3650, one of these devices

(3, 1).clue: This city has the ruins of forums of 5 rulers still standing, including Trajan & Nerva

(4, 1).clue: Russian thistle is one type of this large weed that breaks off & drifts along with the wind

(5, 1).clue: Yale graduate Garry Trudeau began to syndicate this comic strip nationally in 1970

(1, 2).clue: The public library in Salinas, Calif. is named for this Nobel Prize-winning author born in Salinas in 1902

(2, 2).clue: X-2 isn't a Marvel super hero game, it's the sequel to the 10th game in this long-running Japanese RPG series

(3, 2).clue: This capital is home to Jawaharlal Nehru University

(4, 2).clue: This great African-American botanist quipped that "A weed is a flower growing in the wrong place"

(5, 2).clue: This 1985 Yale graduate won her second Oscar for her role in "The Silence of the Lambs"

(6, 2).clue: It can be done to a book, a joke or a smile

(1, 3).clue: The James Madison, Thomas Jefferson & John Adams buildings provide about 65 acres of floor space for this library

(2, 3).clue: This 1982 cult film set in a computer was updated in 2003 with gameplay that includes the following

(3, 3).clue: This capital lies at the northernmost extremity of a 60-mile fjord

(4, 3).clue: This member of the parsley family that grows wild in Europe & the U.S. is a main flavoring agent in pickles

(5, 3).clue: Among the many prominent Yale Law School graduates is this African-American Supreme Court Justice

(6, 3).clue: Bad news can "set you back on" these

(1, 4).clue: The Family History Library at 35 N. West Temple St. in this state capital has archival info on more than 3 billion names

(2, 4).clue: A bright red Ford Torino & voice-overs by Antonio Fargas (aka Huggy Bear) are in the game of this '70s cop show

(3, 4).clue: Said to be 5,000 years old, this capital city lies between the Anti-Lebanon Mountains & the Syrian Desert

(4, 4).clue: Of the Genus Digitaria, this common weed with a "crustacean" name originally came from Europe

(5, 4).clue: This Asian-American woman famous for her architectural memorials graduated with a B.A. from Yale in 1981

(6, 4).clue: Don't get trapped in one of these, illustrated here by Charlie Brown

(1, 5).clue: Andrew himself dedicated this city's Carnegie Library in 1895

(2, 5).clue: For 2004, EA has brought this game, popular in Europe, to American PCs and PlayStations

(3, 5).clue: This capital lies near the junction of the Pilcomayo & Paraguay Rivers

(4, 5).clue: Orange hawkweed is also called the "Devil's" type of this artistic tool

(5, 5).clue: This "Sinners in the Hands of an Angry God" orator was only 17 when he graduated from Yale in 1720

(6, 5).clue: To "follow" this comes from card games such as bridge

(1, 1).clue: Johnson State College & the University of Wisconsin

(2, 1).clue: He says Pepe Le Pew & Keith Richards inspired him as Capt. Jack Sparrow in "Pirates of the Caribbean"

(3, 1).clue: In Japanese myth, Inari, not Uncle Ben, is the god of this

(4, 1).clue: (Sofia gives the clue from a football field in New Haven, Connecticut.) Yale fans first sang "Boola Boola" at a football game in 1900, when Yale beat this team 28-0

(5, 1).clue: At the start of the Civil War, this crop accounted for 2/3 of U.S. exports

(6, 1).clue: (Sarah gives the clue from Barcelona, Spain.) In Spain, this word isn't used to hail Vinny or Guido. It means "I", as in the title of a Picasso self-portrait

(1, 2).clue: Michigan State & Case Western Reserve University

(2, 2).clue: This tart-tongued Brit from "American Idol" is an executive producer of the dating show "Cupid"

(3, 2).clue: In Egyptian myth the first men & women were fashioned out of this, on a potter's wheel

(4, 2).clue: Excluding the state quarter, they're the 2 current pieces of money with the likeness of Abraham Lincoln

(5, 2).clue: Ben Franklin changed Jefferson's "We hold these truths to be sacred and undeniable" to this
(5, 2).correct response: "We hold these truths to be self-evident"

(6, 2).clue: The words seen here mean "yes" & "no" in this language

(2, 3).clue: Your goal is to name this U.K. soccer star, who married Victoria Adams (aka Posh Spice) in 1999

(3, 3).clue: (Jimmy gives the clue from Rockefeller Center in New York.) Paul Manship's sculpture depicts this figure from Greek mythology, stealing fire from the gods as a gift for mankind

(4, 3).clue: In 1947, to go along with its motorcycles, this company introduced its classic black leather jacket

(5, 3).clue: Criticized by colleagues in 1839 he said, "I had rather be right than be President"

(6, 3).clue: (Sarah gives the clue from Munich, Germany.) In an English-German dictionary, this word can become quadrat or platz, as in Marienplatz, below us

(1, 4).clue: Washington State & the University of Houston

(2, 4).clue: The master prankster behind MTV's "Punk'd", he's also an investor in the L.A. restaurant Dolce

(3, 4).clue: The riddle of the Sphinx was so "complex" that only he could solve it

(4, 4).clue: Elizabeth Bennet in this novel was reportedly Jane Austen's favorite of all her heroines

(5, 4).clue: This senator who died in 2003 came in third in the 1948 presidential race

(6, 4).clue: In Portuguese this common English questioning word is onde (1 letter shorter than in Spanish)

(1, 5).clue: The Florida Institute of Technology & the University of Pittsburgh

(3, 5).clue: This most famous of the snake-haired gorgons wound up with her head cut off & placed on the shield of Athena

(4, 5).clue: The Sultanate of Brunei occupies the northern coast of this island

(5, 5).clue: Andrew Jackson had this captured leader & namesake of an 1830s war put on tour in the East as a trophy

(6, 5).clue: Many words derived from this language begin with al-, like alcove, alchemy & Alhambra

(0, 0).clue: These 2 British astronomers were sent to America in 1763 to settle a land dispute
